occurrences.sentence: Enter Dogberry and Verges,with the Watch.DOGBERRY.
but they should suffer salvation, body and soul.DOGBERRY.
Well, give them their charge, neighbour Dogberry.DOGBERRY.
Hugh Oatcake, sir, or George Seacoal; for they can write and read.DOGBERRY.
Both which, Master Constable,—DOGBERRY.
How, if a’ will not stand?DOGBERRY.
If he will not stand when he is bidden, he is none of the Prince’ssubjects.DOGBERRY.
We will rather sleep than talk: we know what belongs to a watch.DOGBERRY.
How if they will not?DOGBERRY.
Well, sir.DOGBERRY.
If we know him to be a thief, shall we not lay hands on him?DOGBERRY.
You have been always called a merciful man, partner.DOGBERRY.
How if the nurse be asleep and will not hear us?DOGBERRY.
’Tis very true.DOGBERRY.
Nay, by’r lady, that I think, a’ cannot.DOGBERRY.
By’r lady, I think it be so.DOGBERRY.
Well, masters, we hear our charge: let us go sit here uponthe church bench till two, and then all to bed.DOGBERRY.
What would you with me, honest neighbour?DOGBERRY.
Brief, I pray you; for you see it is a busy time with me.DOGBERRY.
What is it, my good friends?DOGBERRY.
Yes, I thank God, I am as honest as any man living, that is an oldman and no honester than I.DOGBERRY.
Comparisons are odorous: palabras, neighbour Verges.LEONATO.Neighbours, you are tedious.DOGBERRY.
ah?DOGBERRY.
Marry, sir, our watch tonight, excepting your worship’spresence, ha’ ta’en a couple of as arrant knaves as any inMessina.DOGBERRY.
Indeed, neighbour, he comes too short of you.DOGBERRY.
I must leave you.DOGBERRY.
Take their examination yourself, and bring it me: I am now ingreat haste, as may appear unto you.DOGBERRY.
[Exeunt Leonato and Messenger.]DOGBERRY.
And we must do it wisely.DOGBERRY.
Enter Dogberry, Verges, and Sexton, in gowns; and the Watch, with Conrade andBorachio.DOGBERRY.
a stool and a cushion for the sexton.SEXTON.Which be the malefactors?DOGBERRY.
let them comebefore Master Constable.DOGBERRY.
What is your name, friend?BORACHIO.Borachio.DOGBERRY.
I am a gentleman, sir, and my name is Conrade.DOGBERRY.
Yea, sir, we hope.DOGBERRY.
Marry, sir, we say we are none.DOGBERRY.
Sir, I say to you we are none.DOGBERRY.
Master Constable, you go not the way to examine: you must callforth the watch that are their accusers.DOGBERRY.
This man said, sir, that Don John, the Prince’sbrother, was a villain.DOGBERRY.
Master Constable,—DOGBERRY.
Marry, that he had received a thousand ducats of Don Johnfor accusing the Lady Hero wrongfully.DOGBERRY.
And that Count Claudio did mean, upon his words, to disgraceHero before the whole assembly, and not marry her.DOGBERRY.
[Exit.]DOGBERRY.
Off, coxcomb!DOGBERRY.
you are an ass; you are an ass.DOGBERRY.
Didhe not say my brother was fled?Enter Dogberry, Verges,  and the Watch, withConrade and Borachio.DOGBERRY.
Officers, what offence have these men done?DOGBERRY.
now thy image doth appearIn the rare semblance that I lov’d it first.DOGBERRY.
No, by my soul she was not;Nor knew not what she did when she spoke to me;But always hath been just and virtuousIn anything that I do know by her.DOGBERRY.
I thank thee for thy care and honest pains.DOGBERRY.
There’s for thy pains.DOGBERRY.
Go, I discharge thee of thy prisoner, and I thank thee.DOGBERRY.
Enter Don John and Conrade.
Enter Borachio and Conrade.BORACHIO.
What, Conrade!WATCH.
Conrade, I say!CONRADE.
Enter Dogberry, Verges, and Sexton, in gowns; and the Watch, with Conrade andBorachio.DOGBERRY.
I am a gentleman, sir, and my name is Conrade.DOGBERRY.
Write down Master gentleman Conrade.
Didhe not say my brother was fled?Enter Dogberry, Verges,  and the Watch, withConrade and Borachio.DOGBERRY.
My cousin means Signior Benedick of Padua.
Faith, niece, you tax Signior Benedick too much; but he’llbe meet with you, I doubt it not.
There is a kind of merry warbetwixt Signior Benedick and her; they never meet but there’s askirmish of wit between them.
If he have caught the Benedick, it will cost him a thousandpound ere he be cured.
Enter Don Pedro, Don John, Claudio, Benedick,Balthasar and Others.DON PEDRO.
Signior Benedick, no; for then were you a child.DON PEDRO.
You have it full, Benedick: we may guess by this what you are,being a man.
I wonder that you will still be talking, Signior Benedick:nobody marks you.BENEDICK.
Is it possible Disdain should die while she hath such meet foodto feed it as Signior Benedick?
That is the sum of all, Leonato: Signior Claudio, and SigniorBenedick, my dear friend Leonato hath invited you all.
[Exeunt all but Benedick and Claudio.]CLAUDIO.
Benedick, didst thou note the daughter of Signior Leonato?BENEDICK.

The savage bull may; but if ever the sensible Benedick bear it,pluck off the bull’s horns and set them in my forehead; and let mebe vilely painted, and in such great letters as they write, ‘Here isgood horse to hire,’ let them signify under my sign ‘Here youmay see Benedick the married man.’CLAUDIO.
In the meantime,good Signior Benedick, repair to Leonato’s: commend me to himand tell him I will not fail him at supper; for indeed he hath madegreat preparation.BENEDICK.
The sixth of July: your loving friend, Benedick.BENEDICK.
He were an excellent man that were made just in the mid-waybetween him and Benedick: the one is too like an image, and says nothing;and the other too like my lady’s eldest son, evermore tattling.
Then half Signior Benedick’s tongue in Count John’smouth, and half Count John’s melancholy in Signior Benedick’sface—BEATRICE.
Enter Don Pedro, Claudio, Benedick, Balthasar, DonJohn, Borachio, Margaret, Ursula and Others, masked.DON PEDRO.
Well, this was SigniorBenedick that said so.BENEDICK.
Are you not Signior Benedick?CLAUDIO.
Thus answer I in name of Benedick,But hear these ill news with the ears of Claudio.’Tis certain so; the Prince wooss for himself.
Re-enter Benedick.BENEDICK.
[Exit.]DON PEDRO.Come, lady, come; you have lost the heart of Signior Benedick.BEATRICE.
She were an excellent wife for Benedick.
I will in the interimundertake one of Hercules’ labours, which is, to bring SigniorBenedick and the Lady Beatrice into a mountain of affection the one withthe other.
And Benedick is not the unhopefullest husband that I know.

I will teach you how to humour your cousin, that sheshall fall in love with Benedick; and I, with your two helps, will sopractise on Benedick that, in despite of his quick wit and his queasystomach, he shall fall in love with Beatrice.
Enter Benedick.BENEDICK.
See you where Benedick hath hid himself?
[Exeunt Balthasar and Musicians.]Come hither, Leonato: what was it you told me of today, that your nieceBeatrice was in love with Signior Benedick?CLAUDIO.
No, nor I neither; but most wonderful that she should sodote on Signior Benedick, whom she hath in all outward behavioursseemed ever to abhor.BENEDICK.
I would have sworn it had, my lord; especially against Benedick.BENEDICK.
Hath she made her affection known to Benedick?LEONATO.
when she had writ it, and was reading it over, she foundBenedick and Beatrice between the sheet?CLAUDIO.
Then down upon her knees she falls, weeps, sobs, beats her heart,tears her hair, prays, curses; ‘O sweet Benedick!
It were good that Benedick knew of it by some other, if shewill not discover it.
In everything but in loving Benedick.LEONATO.O!
I pray you, tell Benedick ofit, and hear what he will say.LEONATO.Were it good, think you?CLAUDIO.
Shall we go seek Benedick and tell him of her love?CLAUDIO.Never tell him, my lord: let her wear it out with good counsel.
I love Benedick well, and I could wish he would modestlyexamine himself, to see how much he is unworthy so good a lady.LEONATO.
Now, Ursula, when Beatrice doth come,As we do trace this alley up and down,Our talk must only be of Benedick:When I do name him, let it be thy partTo praise him more than ever man did merit.
My talk to thee must be how BenedickIs sick in love with Beatrice: of this matterIs little Cupid’s crafty arrow made,That only wounds by hearsay.
But are you sureThat Benedick loves Beatrice so entirely?HERO.
But I persuaded them, if they lov’d Benedick,To wish him wrestle with affection,And never to let Beatrice know of it.
Therefore let Benedick, like cover’d fire,Consume away in sighs, waste inwardly:It were a better death than die with mocks,Which is as bad as die with tickling.
No; rather I will go to Benedick,And counsel him to fight against his passion.
She cannot be so much without true judgment,—Having so swift and excellent a witAs she is priz’d to have,—as to refuseSo rare a gentleman as Signior Benedick.HERO.
Signior Benedick,For shape, for bearing, argument and valour,Goes foremost in report through Italy.

And, Benedick, love on; I will requite thee,Taming my wild heart to thy loving hand:If thou dost love, my kindness shall incite theeTo bind our loves up in a holy band;For others say thou dost deserve, and IBelieve it better than reportingly.
Enter Don Pedro, Claudio, Benedick and Leonato.DON PEDRO.

Iwill only be bold with Benedick for his company; for, from the crown ofhis head to the sole of his foot, he is all mirth; he hath twice or thricecut Cupid’s bowstring, and the little hangman dare not shoot at him.
[Exeunt Benedick and Leonato.]DON PEDRO.

Yet Benedick was such another, and now is hebecome a man: he swore he would never marry; and yet now, in despite ofhis heart, he eats his meat without grudging: and how you may beconverted, I know not; but methinks you look with your eyes as other womendo.BEATRICE.
Madam, withdraw: the Prince, the Count, Signior Benedick, DonJohn, and all the gallants of the town are come to fetch you to church.
Enter Don Pedro, Don John, Leonato, Friar Francis,Claudio, Benedick, Hero, Beatrice &c.LEONATO.
SigniorBenedick!
Enter Benedick.DON PEDRO.
But when shall we set the savage bull’s horns on thesensible Benedick’s head?CLAUDIO.
Yea, and text underneath, ‘Here dwells Benedick themarried man!’BENEDICK.
Enter Benedick and Margaret,meeting.BENEDICK.
Enter Leonato, Antonio, Benedick, Beatrice,Margaret, Ursula, Friar Francis and Hero.FRIAR.
[Exit Antonio.]DON PEDRO.Good morrow, Benedick.
And here’s another,Writ in my cousin’s hand, stolen from her pocket,Containing her affection unto Benedick.BENEDICK.
[Kisses her.]DON PEDRO.How dost thou, Benedick, the married man?BENEDICK.
Enter Leonato, Hero, Beatrice and others,with a Messenger.LEONATO.
Enter Leonato, Antonio, Hero, Beatrice andothers.
No; but to the gate; and there will the Devil meet me, like anold cuckold, with horns on his head, and say, ‘Get you to heaven,Beatrice, get you to heaven; here’s no place for you maids.’
But, thatmy Lady Beatrice should know me, and not know me!
Yea, but so I amapt to do myself wrong; I am not so reputed: it is the base though bitterdisposition of Beatrice that puts the world into her person, and so givesme out.
The Lady Beatrice hath a quarrel to you: the gentleman thatdanced with her told her she is much wronged by you.BENEDICK.

I would to God some scholar would conjure her, for certainly,while she is here, a man may live as quiet in hell as in a sanctuary; andpeople sin upon purpose because they would go thither; so indeed, alldisquiet, horror and perturbation follow her.Re-enter Claudio, Beatrice, Hero and Leonato.DON PEDRO.
Lady Beatrice, I will get you one.BEATRICE.
I will in the interimundertake one of Hercules’ labours, which is, to bring SigniorBenedick and the Lady Beatrice into a mountain of affection the one withthe other.

I will teach you how to humour your cousin, that sheshall fall in love with Benedick; and I, with your two helps, will sopractise on Benedick that, in despite of his quick wit and his queasystomach, he shall fall in love with Beatrice.
[Exeunt Balthasar and Musicians.]Come hither, Leonato: what was it you told me of today, that your nieceBeatrice was in love with Signior Benedick?CLAUDIO.
when she had writ it, and was reading it over, she foundBenedick and Beatrice between the sheet?CLAUDIO.
Here comes Beatrice.
Enter Beatrice.BEATRICE.
Fair Beatrice, I thank you for your pains.BEATRICE.

Good Margaret, run thee to the parlour;There shalt thou find my cousin BeatriceProposing with the Prince and Claudio:Whisper her ear, and tell her, I and UrsalaWalk in the orchard, and our whole discourseIs all of her; say that thou overheard’st us,And bid her steal into the pleached bower,Where honey-suckles, ripen’d by the sun,
Now, Ursula, when Beatrice doth come,As we do trace this alley up and down,Our talk must only be of Benedick:When I do name him, let it be thy partTo praise him more than ever man did merit.
My talk to thee must be how BenedickIs sick in love with Beatrice: of this matterIs little Cupid’s crafty arrow made,That only wounds by hearsay.
Enter Beatrice behind.
Now begin;For look where Beatrice, like a lapwing, runsClose by the ground, to hear our conference.

The pleasant’st angling is to see the fishCut with her golden oars the silver stream,And greedily devour the treacherous bait:So angle we for Beatrice; who even nowIs couched in the woodbine coverture.
But are you sureThat Benedick loves Beatrice so entirely?HERO.
But I persuaded them, if they lov’d Benedick,To wish him wrestle with affection,And never to let Beatrice know of it.
Doth not the gentlemanDeserve as full as fortunate a bedAs ever Beatrice shall couch upon?HERO.

But Nature never fram’d a woman’s heartOf prouder stuff than that of Beatrice;Disdain and scorn ride sparkling in her eyes,Misprising what they look on, and her witValues itself so highly, that to herAll matter else seems weak.
No; not to be so odd, and from all fashions,As Beatrice is, cannot be commendable.
For my life, to break with him about Beatrice.CLAUDIO.’Tis even so.
Hero and Margaret have by this playedtheir parts with Beatrice, and then the two bears will not bite oneanother when they meet.
Good Ursula, wake my cousin Beatrice, and desire her to rise.
None, I think, and it be the right husband andthe right wife; otherwise ’tis light, and not heavy: ask my LadyBeatrice else; here she comes.
Enter Beatrice.
Enter Don Pedro, Don John, Leonato, Friar Francis,Claudio, Benedick, Hero, Beatrice &c.LEONATO.
Lady Beatrice, have you wept all this while?BEATRICE.
By my sword, Beatrice, thou lovest me.BEATRICE.
What offence, sweet Beatrice?BEATRICE.
Tarry, sweet Beatrice.BEATRICE.
Beatrice,—BEATRICE.
Hear me, Beatrice,—BEATRICE.
Nay, but Beatrice,—BEATRICE.
Tarry, good Beatrice.
I’ll tell thee how Beatrice praised thy wit theother day.
In most profound earnest; and, I’ll warrant you, forthe love of Beatrice.DON PEDRO.
Pray thee, sweet Mistress Margaret, deserve well at my hands byhelping me to the speech of Beatrice.MARGARET.
A most manly wit, Margaret; it will not hurt a woman: and so, Ipray thee, call Beatrice.
Well, I will call Beatrice to you, who I think hath legs.BENEDICK.
Sweet Beatrice, wouldst thou come when I called thee?BEATRICE.
An old, an old instance, Beatrice, that lived in the time ofgood neighbours.
Enter Leonato, Antonio, Benedick, Beatrice,Margaret, Ursula, Friar Francis and Hero.FRIAR.
Which is Beatrice?BEATRICE.
For here’s a paper written in his hand,A halting sonnet of his own pure brain,Fashion’d to Beatrice.HERO.

I had well hoped thou wouldst have denied Beatrice, that I mighthave cudgelled thee out of thy single life, to make thee a double-dealer;which, out of question, thou wilt be, if my cousin do not look exceedingnarrowly to thee.BENEDICK.
I learn in this letter that Don Pedro of Arragon comes this nightto Messina.MESSENGER.
I find here that Don Pedro hath bestowed much honour on ayoung Florentine called Claudio.
Much deserved on his part, and equally remembered by Don Pedro.
Don Pedro is approached.
Enter Don Pedro, Don John, Claudio, Benedick,Balthasar and Others.DON PEDRO.
Re-enter Don Pedro.
Don Pedro is returned to seek you.DON PEDRO.
Enter Don Pedro, Claudio, Benedick, Balthasar, DonJohn, Borachio, Margaret, Ursula and Others, masked.DON PEDRO.
Re-enter Don Pedro.DON PEDRO.

BORACHIO.Go then; find me a meet hour to draw Don Pedro and the CountClaudio alone: tell them that you know that Hero loves me; intend a kindof zeal both to the Prince and Claudio, as—in love of your brother’shonour, who hath made this match, and his friend’s reputation, whois thus like to be cozened with the semblance of a maid,—that you havediscovered thus.
[Withdraws.]Enter Don Pedro, Leonato and Claudio, followed by Balthasarand Musicians.DON PEDRO.
ay:—[Aside to Don Pedro]
[Exeunt Don Pedro, Claudio and Leonato.]BENEDICK.
Enter Don Pedro, Claudio, Benedick and Leonato.DON PEDRO.
Enter Don Pedro, Don John, Leonato, Friar Francis,Claudio, Benedick, Hero, Beatrice &c.LEONATO.
[Exeunt Don Pedro, Don John and Claudio.]BENEDICK.
Enter Don Pedro and Claudio.DON PEDRO.
[Exeunt Don Pedro and Claudio.]LEONATO.
Enter Don Pedro, Claudio and Attendants,with music and tapers.
Enter Don Pedro and Claudio,with Attendants.DON PEDRO.
I find here that Don Pedro hath bestowed much honour on ayoung Florentine called Claudio.
He is most in the company of the right noble Claudio.BEATRICE.
God help thenoble Claudio!
Enter Don Pedro, Don John, Claudio, Benedick,Balthasar and Others.DON PEDRO.
That is the sum of all, Leonato: Signior Claudio, and SigniorBenedick, my dear friend Leonato hath invited you all.
[Exeunt all but Benedick and Claudio.]CLAUDIO.
You hear, Count Claudio: I can be secret as a dumb man; I wouldhave you think so; but on my allegiance mark you this, on my allegiance:he is in love.
Dost thou affect her, Claudio?CLAUDIO.
I know we shall have revelling tonight:I will assume thy part in some disguise,And tell fair Hero I am Claudio;

The Prince and Count Claudio, walking in a thick-pleachedalley in my orchard, were thus much overheard by a man of mine: the Princediscovered to Claudio that he loved my niece your daughter and meant toacknowledge it this night in a dance; and if he found her accordant, hemeant to take the present time by the top and instantly break with you ofit.
the most exquisite Claudio?BORACHIO.

Being entertained for a perfumer, as I was smoking a musty room,comes me the Prince and Claudio, hand in hand, in sad conference: I whiptme behind the arras, and there heard it agreed upon that the Prince shouldwoo Hero for himself, and having obtained her, give her to Count Claudio.DON JOHN.
Enter Don Pedro, Claudio, Benedick, Balthasar, DonJohn, Borachio, Margaret, Ursula and Others, masked.DON PEDRO.
Then exeunt all but Don John, Borachioand Claudio.]DON JOHN.
And that is Claudio: I know him by his bearing.
Thus answer I in name of Benedick,But hear these ill news with the ears of Claudio.’Tis certain so; the Prince wooss for himself.
Count Claudio?CLAUDIO.

I would to God some scholar would conjure her, for certainly,while she is here, a man may live as quiet in hell as in a sanctuary; andpeople sin upon purpose because they would go thither; so indeed, alldisquiet, horror and perturbation follow her.Re-enter Claudio, Beatrice, Hero and Leonato.DON PEDRO.
I have brought Count Claudio, whom you sent me to seek.DON PEDRO.
Here, Claudio, I have wooedin thy name, and fair Hero is won; I have broke with her father, and, hisgood will obtained; name the day of marriage, and God give thee joy!
Count Claudio, when mean you to go to church?CLAUDIO.
Come, you shake the head at so long a breathing; but, I warrantthee, Claudio, the time shall not go dully by us.
It is so; the Count Claudio shall marry the daughter of Leonato.BORACHIO.

Go you to the Princeyour brother; spare not to tell him, that he hath wronged his honour inmarrying the renowned Claudio,—whose estimation do you mightily holdup,—to a contaminated stale, such a one as Hero.DON JOHN.
Proof enough to misuse the Prince, to vex Claudio, to undo Hero,and kill Leonato.

BORACHIO.Go then; find me a meet hour to draw Don Pedro and the CountClaudio alone: tell them that you know that Hero loves me; intend a kindof zeal both to the Prince and Claudio, as—in love of your brother’shonour, who hath made this match, and his friend’s reputation, whois thus like to be cozened with the semblance of a maid,—that you havediscovered thus.

They will scarcely believe this without trial: offer theminstances, which shall bear no less likelihood than to see me at herchamber window, hear me call Margaret Hero, hear Margaret term me Claudio;and bring them to see this the very night before the intended wedding: forin the meantime I will so fashion the matter that Hero shall be absent;and there shall appear such seeming truth of Hero’s disloyalty, thatjealousy shall be called assurance, and all the preparation overthrown.

I do much wonder that one man, seeing how much another man is a fool whenhe dedicates his behaviours to love, will, after he hath laughed at suchshallow follies in others, become the argument of his own scorn by fallingin love: and such a man is Claudio.
[Withdraws.]Enter Don Pedro, Leonato and Claudio, followed by Balthasarand Musicians.DON PEDRO.
She will sit you; [To Claudio] Youheard my daughter tell you how.CLAUDIO.
[Exeunt Don Pedro, Claudio and Leonato.]BENEDICK.

Good Margaret, run thee to the parlour;There shalt thou find my cousin BeatriceProposing with the Prince and Claudio:Whisper her ear, and tell her, I and UrsalaWalk in the orchard, and our whole discourseIs all of her; say that thou overheard’st us,And bid her steal into the pleached bower,Where honey-suckles, ripen’d by the sun,
He is the only man of Italy,Always excepted my dear Claudio.URSULA.
Enter Don Pedro, Claudio, Benedick and Leonato.DON PEDRO.
If it please you; yet Count Claudio may hear, for what I wouldspeak of concerns him.DON PEDRO.
[To Claudio.]

Not so neither; but know, that I have tonight wooed Margaret,the Lady Hero’s gentlewoman, by the name of Hero: she leans me outat her mistress’ chamber window, bids me a thousand times goodnight,—I tell this tale vilely:—I should first tell thee how the Prince,Claudio, and my master, planted and placed and possessed by my master DonJohn, saw afar off in the orchard this amiable encounter.CONRADE.

Two of them did, the Prince and Claudio; but the devil mymaster, knew she was Margaret; and partly by his oaths, which firstpossessed them, partly by the dark night, which did deceive them, butchiefly by my villainy, which did confirm any slander that Don John hadmade, away went Claudio enraged; swore he would meet her, as he wasappointed, next morning at the temple, and there, before the wholecongregation, shame her with what he saw o’er night, and send herhome again without a husband.
Enter Don Pedro, Don John, Leonato, Friar Francis,Claudio, Benedick, Hero, Beatrice &c.LEONATO.
[Exeunt Don Pedro, Don John and Claudio.]BENEDICK.
and Claudio lie,Who lov’d her so, that, speaking of her foulness,Wash’d it with tears?

So will it fare with Claudio:When he shall hear she died upon his words,The idea of her life shall sweetly creepInto his study of imagination,And every lovely organ of her lifeShall come apparell’d in more precious habit,More moving, delicate, and full of lifeInto the eye and prospect of his soul,

Signior Leonato, let the friar advise you:And though you know my inwardness and loveIs very much unto the Prince and Claudio,Yet, by mine honour, I will deal in thisAs secretly and justly as your soulShould with your body.
Kill Claudio.BENEDICK.
Is Claudio thine enemy?BEATRICE.
Think you in your soul the Count Claudio hath wronged Hero?BEATRICE.
By this hand, Claudio shall render me a dearaccount.
And that Count Claudio did mean, upon his words, to disgraceHero before the whole assembly, and not marry her.DOGBERRY.
My soul doth tell me Hero is belied;And that shall Claudio know; so shall the Prince,And all of them that thus dishonour her.ANTONIO.
Here comes the Prince and Claudio hastily.
Enter Don Pedro and Claudio.DON PEDRO.
Know, Claudio, to thy head,Thou hast so wrong’d mine innocent child and meThat I am forc’d to lay my reverence by,And, with grey hairs and bruise of many days,Do challenge thee to trial of a man.
Thine, Claudio; thine, I say.
[Aside to Claudio.]
I do embrace your offer; and disposeFor henceforth of poor Claudio.LEONATO.
[Exeunt Don Pedro and Claudio.]LEONATO.
‘Then’ is spoken; fare you well now: and yet, ere Igo, let me go with that I came for; which is, with knowing what hathpassed between you and Claudio.BENEDICK.
But I must tell thee plainly, Claudio undergoes my challenge,and either I must shortly hear from him, or I will subscribe him a coward.
Yonder’s old coil athome: it is proved, my Lady Hero hath been falsely accused, the Prince andClaudio mightily abused; and Don John is the author of all, who is fledand gone.
Enter Don Pedro, Claudio and Attendants,with music and tapers.

So are the Prince and Claudio, who accus’d herUpon the error that you heard debated:But Margaret was in some fault for this,Although against her will, as it appearsIn the true course of all the question.
And so am I, being else by faith enforc’dTo call young Claudio to a reckoning for it.LEONATO.
Well, daughter, and you gentlewomen all,Withdraw into a chamber by yourselves,And when I send for you, come hither mask’d:The Prince and Claudio promis’d by this hourTo visit me.
You know your office, brother;You must be father to your brother’s daughter,And give her to young Claudio.ANTONIO.Which I will do with confirm’d countenance.BENEDICK.
The sight whereof I think, you had from me,From Claudio, and the Prince.
Here comes the Prince and Claudio.
Enter Don Pedro and Claudio,with Attendants.DON PEDRO.
Good morrow, Prince; good morrow, Claudio:We here attend you.
Why, then, your uncle and the Prince and ClaudioHave been deceived; for they swore you did.BEATRICE.
For thy part, Claudio, I did think to havebeaten thee; but, in that thou art like to be my kinsman, liveunbruised, and love my cousin.
I learn in this letter that Don Pedro of Arragon comes this nightto Messina.MESSENGER.
How many gentlemen have you lost in this action?MESSENGER.
MESSENGER.
Did he break out into tears?MESSENGER.
I pray you, is Signior Mountanto returned from the wars or no?MESSENGER.
And a good soldier to a lady; but what is he to a lord?MESSENGER.
Is there no young squarer now that will make a voyage withhim to the devil?MESSENGER.
Enter Leonato, Hero, Beatrice and others,with a Messenger.LEONATO.
Good Signior Leonato, you are come to meet your trouble: thefashion of the world is to avoid cost, and you encounter it.
If Signior Leonato be her father, she would not have his head onher shoulders for all Messina, as like him as she is.BEATRICE.
That is the sum of all, Leonato: Signior Claudio, and SigniorBenedick, my dear friend Leonato hath invited you all.
Your hand, Leonato; we will go together.
Benedick, didst thou note the daughter of Signior Leonato?BENEDICK.
What secret hath held you here, that you followed not toLeonato’s?BENEDICK.
Mark howshort his answer is: with Hero, Leonato’s short daughter.
In the meantime,good Signior Benedick, repair to Leonato’s: commend me to himand tell him I will not fail him at supper; for indeed he hath madegreat preparation.BENEDICK.
Hath Leonato any son, my lord?DON PEDRO.
A room in Leonato’s house.
Enter Leonato and Antonio,meeting.
Another room in Leonato’s house.
I came yonder from a great supper: the Prince your brother isroyally entertained by Leonato; and I can give you intelligence of anintended marriage.
Marry, on Hero, the daughter and heir of Leonato.DON JOHN.
Enter Leonato, Antonio, Hero, Beatrice andothers.

I would to God some scholar would conjure her, for certainly,while she is here, a man may live as quiet in hell as in a sanctuary; andpeople sin upon purpose because they would go thither; so indeed, alldisquiet, horror and perturbation follow her.Re-enter Claudio, Beatrice, Hero and Leonato.DON PEDRO.
It is so; the Count Claudio shall marry the daughter of Leonato.BORACHIO.
Proof enough to misuse the Prince, to vex Claudio, to undo Hero,and kill Leonato.
Leonato’s Garden.
[Withdraws.]Enter Don Pedro, Leonato and Claudio, followed by Balthasarand Musicians.DON PEDRO.
[Exeunt Balthasar and Musicians.]Come hither, Leonato: what was it you told me of today, that your nieceBeatrice was in love with Signior Benedick?CLAUDIO.
[Exeunt Don Pedro, Claudio and Leonato.]BENEDICK.
A Room in Leonato’s House.
Enter Don Pedro, Claudio, Benedick and Leonato.DON PEDRO.
[Exeunt Benedick and Leonato.]DON PEDRO.
Even she: Leonato’s Hero, your Hero, every man’s Hero.CLAUDIO.
I pray you, watch aboutSignior Leonato’s door; for the wedding being there tomorrow,there is a great coil tonight.
Scene V. Another Room in Leonato’s House.
Enter Leonato and Dogberryand Verges.
[Exeunt Leonato and Messenger.]DOGBERRY.
Enter Don Pedro, Don John, Leonato, Friar Francis,Claudio, Benedick, Hero, Beatrice &c.LEONATO.
There, Leonato, take her back again:Give not this rotten orange to your friend;She’s
I know what you would say: if I have known her,You will say she did embrace me as a husband,And so extenuate the forehand sin: No, Leonato,I never tempted her with word too large;
Leonato, stand I here?Is this the Prince?

Leonato, I am sorry you must hear: upon my honour,Myself, my brother, and this grieved Count,Did see her, hear her, at that hour last night,Talk with a ruffian at her chamber window;Who hath indeed, most like a liberal villain,Confess’d the vile encounters they have hadA thousand times in secret.

Signior Leonato, let the friar advise you:And though you know my inwardness and loveIs very much unto the Prince and Claudio,Yet, by mine honour, I will deal in thisAs secretly and justly as your soulShould with your body.
[Exeunt Friar, Hero and Leonato.]BENEDICK.
MasterConstable, let these men be bound, and brought to Leonato’s: I willgo before and show him their examination.
Enter Leonato and Antonio.ANTONIO.
We have some haste, Leonato.LEONATO.
[Exeunt Leonato and Antonio.]
Leonato and his brother.
Come, bring away the plaintiffs: by this time our sexton hathreformed Signior Leonato of the matter.
Here, here comes Master Signior Leonato, and the sexton too.Re-enter Leonato, Antonio and the Sexton.LEONATO.Which is the villain?
Is this the monument of Leonato?A LORD.
Come, let us hence, and put on other weeds;And then to Leonato’s we will go.
Enter Leonato, Antonio, Benedick, Beatrice,Margaret, Ursula, Friar Francis and Hero.FRIAR.
Signior Leonato, truth it is, good signior,Your niece regards me with an eye of favour.LEONATO.
Enter Don Pedro, Claudio, Benedick, Balthasar, DonJohn, Borachio, Margaret, Ursula and Others, masked.DON PEDRO.
I think I told your lordship, a year since, how much I am in thefavour of Margaret, the waiting gentlewoman to Hero.

They will scarcely believe this without trial: offer theminstances, which shall bear no less likelihood than to see me at herchamber window, hear me call Margaret Hero, hear Margaret term me Claudio;and bring them to see this the very night before the intended wedding: forin the meantime I will so fashion the matter that Hero shall be absent;and there shall appear such seeming truth of Hero’s disloyalty, thatjealousy shall be called assurance, and all the preparation overthrown.
Enter Hero, Margaret and Ursula.HERO.

Good Margaret, run thee to the parlour;There shalt thou find my cousin BeatriceProposing with the Prince and Claudio:Whisper her ear, and tell her, I and UrsalaWalk in the orchard, and our whole discourseIs all of her; say that thou overheard’st us,And bid her steal into the pleached bower,Where honey-suckles, ripen’d by the sun,
Hero and Margaret have by this playedtheir parts with Beatrice, and then the two bears will not bite oneanother when they meet.

Not so neither; but know, that I have tonight wooed Margaret,the Lady Hero’s gentlewoman, by the name of Hero: she leans me outat her mistress’ chamber window, bids me a thousand times goodnight,—I tell this tale vilely:—I should first tell thee how the Prince,Claudio, and my master, planted and placed and possessed by my master DonJohn, saw afar off in the orchard this amiable encounter.CONRADE.
And thought they Margaret was Hero?BORACHIO.

Two of them did, the Prince and Claudio; but the devil mymaster, knew she was Margaret; and partly by his oaths, which firstpossessed them, partly by the dark night, which did deceive them, butchiefly by my villainy, which did confirm any slander that Don John hadmade, away went Claudio enraged; swore he would meet her, as he wasappointed, next morning at the temple, and there, before the wholecongregation, shame her with what he saw o’er night, and send herhome again without a husband.
Enter Hero, Margaret and Ursula.HERO.

I have deceived even your very eyes: whatyour wisdoms could not discover, these shallow fools have brought tolight; who, in the night overheard me confessing to this man how Don Johnyour brother incensed me to slander the Lady Hero; how you were broughtinto the orchard and saw me court Margaret in Hero’s garments; howyou disgraced her, when you should marry her.
This naughty manShall face to face be brought to Margaret,Who, I believe, was pack’d in all this wrong,Hir’d to it by your brother.
We’ll talk withMargaret,How her acquaintance grew with this lewd fellow.
Enter Benedick and Margaret,meeting.BENEDICK.
Pray thee, sweet Mistress Margaret, deserve well at my hands byhelping me to the speech of Beatrice.MARGARET.
In so high a style, Margaret, that no man living shall come overit; for, in most comely truth, thou deservest it.MARGARET.To have no man come over me!
A most manly wit, Margaret; it will not hurt a woman: and so, Ipray thee, call Beatrice.
If you use them, Margaret, you must put in the pikes with avice; and they are dangerous weapons for maids.
[Exit Margaret.]
Enter Leonato, Antonio, Benedick, Beatrice,Margaret, Ursula, Friar Francis and Hero.FRIAR.

So are the Prince and Claudio, who accus’d herUpon the error that you heard debated:But Margaret was in some fault for this,Although against her will, as it appearsIn the true course of all the question.
Why, then my cousin, Margaret, and Ursula,Are much deceiv’d; for they did swear you did.BENEDICK.
Enter Don Pedro, Claudio, Benedick, Balthasar, DonJohn, Borachio, Margaret, Ursula and Others, masked.DON PEDRO.
Enter Hero, Margaret and Ursula.HERO.
Now, Ursula, when Beatrice doth come,As we do trace this alley up and down,Our talk must only be of Benedick:When I do name him, let it be thy partTo praise him more than ever man did merit.
No, truly, Ursula, she is too disdainful;I know her spirits are as coy and wildAs haggards of the rock.
[Exeunt Hero and Ursula.]BEATRICE.
Enter Hero, Margaret and Ursula.HERO.
Good Ursula, wake my cousin Beatrice, and desire her to rise.
Re-enter Ursula.URSULA.
Help to dress me, good coz, good Meg, good Ursula.
Enter Ursula.
Enter Leonato, Antonio, Benedick, Beatrice,Margaret, Ursula, Friar Francis and Hero.FRIAR.
Why, then my cousin, Margaret, and Ursula,Are much deceiv’d; for they did swear you did.BENEDICK.
Nay, if Cupid have not spent all his quiver in Venice, thouwilt quake for this shortly.BENEDICK.
Nay, mock not, mock not.
In every good thing.BEATRICE.Nay, if they lead to any ill, I will leave them at the next turning.
Nay, pray thee come;Or if thou wilt hold longer argument,Do it in notes.BALTHASAR.
Nay, that’s impossible: she may wear her heart out first.DON PEDRO.
I’ll bring you thither, my lord, if you’llvouchsafe me.DON PEDRO.Nay, that would be as great a soil in the new gloss of yourmarriage, as to show a child his new coat and forbid him to wear it.
Nay, a’ rubs himself with civet: can you smell him out by that?CLAUDIO.
Nay, but his jesting spirit; which is now crept into alute-string, and now governed by stops.
Nay, but I know who loves him.
Nay, that were a punishment too good for them, if they shouldhave any allegiance in them, being chosen for the Prince’s watch.VERGES.
Nay, by’r lady, that I think, a’ cannot.DOGBERRY.
Nay, but Beatrice,—BEATRICE.
Nay, that’s certain: we have the exhibition to examine.SEXTON.
Nay, do not quarrel with us, good old man.
Marry, thou dost wrong me; thou dissembler, thou.Nay, never lay thy hand upon thy sword;I fear thee not.CLAUDIO.
Sir boy, I’ll whip you from your foining fence;Nay, as I am a gentleman, I will.
Nay then, give him another staff: this last was broke cross.DON PEDRO.
‘Nay,’ said I, ‘a good wit.’
‘Nay,’said I, ‘the gentleman is wise.’
‘Nay,’ said I,‘he hath the tongues.’
Nay, an you be a cursing hypocriteonce, you must be looked to.DON PEDRO.
Enter Don Pedro, Don John, Claudio, Benedick,Balthasar and Others.DON PEDRO.
[ToDon John] Let me bid you welcome, my lord: being reconciled tothe Prince your brother, I owe you all duty.
Enter Don John and Conrade.
Then exeunt all but Don John, Borachioand Claudio.]DON JOHN.
[Exeunt Don John and Borachio.]CLAUDIO.
Enter Don John and Borachio.
Enter Don John.DON JOHN.
Therefore know, I have earned of Don John a thousand ducats.CONRADE.

Two of them did, the Prince and Claudio; but the devil mymaster, knew she was Margaret; and partly by his oaths, which firstpossessed them, partly by the dark night, which did deceive them, butchiefly by my villainy, which did confirm any slander that Don John hadmade, away went Claudio enraged; swore he would meet her, as he wasappointed, next morning at the temple, and there, before the wholecongregation, shame her with what he saw o’er night, and send herhome again without a husband.
Enter Don Pedro, Don John, Leonato, Friar Francis,Claudio, Benedick, Hero, Beatrice &c.LEONATO.
[Exeunt Don Pedro, Don John and Claudio.]BENEDICK.
This man said, sir, that Don John, the Prince’sbrother, was a villain.DOGBERRY.
Marry, that he had received a thousand ducats of Don Johnfor accusing the Lady Hero wrongfully.DOGBERRY.

I have deceived even your very eyes: whatyour wisdoms could not discover, these shallow fools have brought tolight; who, in the night overheard me confessing to this man how Don Johnyour brother incensed me to slander the Lady Hero; how you were broughtinto the orchard and saw me court Margaret in Hero’s garments; howyou disgraced her, when you should marry her.
Yonder’s old coil athome: it is proved, my Lady Hero hath been falsely accused, the Prince andClaudio mightily abused; and Don John is the author of all, who is fledand gone.
